title: Mechanical Engineering
author: Debaditya Majumder
description: Prepare to be ratioed by gender

questions.text: In large gas-compression stations (e.g., on a natural gas pipeline), compression is done in several stages as illustrated. After each stage, the gas is cooled at constant pressure back to the inlet temperature ($T_1 = 300\,\text{K}$). A station compresses 10 moles of methane from $P_1$ to $P_{N+1}$ in one isentropic stage. What is the total work done (in kJ)? (Given: $\frac{P_{N+1}}{P_1} = 40$, $\gamma = 1.31$, $R = 8.314$ SI units)
In a 10-stage gas compressor, what is the pressure ratio $\frac{P_4}{P_2}$ required to minimize work? (Given: $\frac{P_{N+1}}{P_1} = 40$, $\gamma = 1.31$)
In a 10-stage gas compressor, what is the total work done (in kJ) if the outlet pressures are optimally chosen to minimize work? (Given: $\frac{P_{N+1}}{P_1} = 40$, $\gamma = 1.31$, $R = 8.314$)
What is the percentage increase in work done if the compression is carried out in a single isentropic stage instead of 10 optimized stages? (Given: $\frac{P_{N+1}}{P_1} = 40$, $\gamma = 1.31$)
If the number of stages approaches a very large number (e.g., $N \gg 10000$), what is the work done in such a case (in kJ)? (Given: $\frac{P_{N+1}}{P_1} = 40$, $\gamma = 1.31$, $R = 8.314$)

What is the percentage increase in work done if compression is done in a single isentropic stage instead of an idealized process with infinite stages? (Given: $\frac{P_{N+1}}{P_1} = 40$, $\gamma = 1.31$)
A fan that consumes 20 W of electric power is claimed to discharge air from a ventilated room at 1.0 kg/s. What should the minimum discharge velocity be to validate this claim?

You are in a breezy room at 20°C. If your body has an exposed area of 1.6 m² and an outer surface temperature of 29°C, with a heat transfer coefficient of 6 W/m²·°C, what is the total rate of heat transfer from your body?

Saturated steam at 1 atm condenses on a vertical plate at 90°C. The condensate drips into a 5L vessel at the same temperature. Given a condensation heat transfer rate of 1150 kJ/s, latent heat of vaporization = 2257×10³, and water's specific heat capacity = 4300, how often (in seconds) should the vessel be replaced to prevent overflow?

Two bodies A ($r_1$ = 1000 km) and B ($r_2$ = 4000 km) are separated by $d = \sqrt{5.6\pi} \times 10^{11}$ km. B is at 1000 K and A is at 0 K. A reflects $\alpha = 0.8$ of incoming radiation. B reflects 0.8 and absorbs 0.2 of incident radiation. How much heat per second does A receive? (Use Stefan–Boltzmann constant $\sigma = 5.6 \times 10^{-8}$ SI units)
